sections.markdown: Young adults are commonly associated with binge drinking in the media. However, the latest data about their relationship with alcohol might surprise you, as might the location of the teetotal capital of Great Britain. Here are 5 facts about drinking habits in Great Britain between 2005 and 2013. ####1. More than one in five adults in Great Britain in 2013 said they were teetotal. The proportion of teetotal young adults (those aged 16 to 24) increased by over 40% between 2005 and 2013. [Download the data.][1] ####2. The proportion of adults who binged^1^ at least once in the previous week decreased from 18% in 2005 to 15% in 2013. This is because the proportion of young adults binge drinking fell by more than a third since 2005, from 29% to 18%. [Download the data.][2] ####3. In 2013 only 1 in 50 young adults^2^ were frequent drinkers^3^ , a fall of more than two-thirds since 2005. [Download the data.][3] ####4. Almost a third of adults in London (32%) said that they do not drink alcohol at all. This was considerably higher than any other region of Great Britain. [Download the data.][4] ####5. Around a third of adults in Scotland and the north of England, who drank in the previous week, had binged at least once, compared with less than a quarter of those in other parts of Great Britain. [Download the data.][5] [1]: https://static.ons.gov.uk/visual/2015/02/CHD_StoryFig_1.csv [2]: https://static.ons.gov.uk/visual/2015/02/CHD_StoryFig_2.csv [3]: https://static.ons.gov.uk/visual/2015/02/CHD_StoryFig_3.csv [4]: https://static.ons.gov.uk/visual/2015/02/CHD_StoryFig_4.csv [5]: https://static.ons.gov.uk/visual/2015/02/CHD_StoryFig_5.csv [6]: mailto:opinions@ons.gov.uk ###Footnotes: 1. In line with the Government’s Alcohol Strategy, binge drinking refers to men who reported drinking more than eight units of alcohol on their heaviest drinking day in the week before interview, and women who drank more than six units. 2. Those aged 16 to 24. 3. Drinking on 5 or more days in the week before interview.
